message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Modeling Echo Chambers and Polarization Dynamics in Social Networks
Paper Abstract: Echo chambers and opinion polarization recently quantified in several sociopolitical contexts and across different social media raise concerns on their potential impact on the spread of misinformation and on the openness of debates. Despite increasing efforts, the dynamics leading to the emergence of these phenomena remain unclear. We propose a model that introduces the dynamics of radicalization as a reinforcing mechanism driving the evolution to extreme opinions from moderate initial conditions. Inspired by empirical findings on social interaction dynamics, we consider agents characterized by heterogeneous activities and homophily. We show that the transition between a global consensus and emerging radicalized states is mostly governed by social influence and by the controversialness of the topic discussed. Compared with empirical data of polarized debates on Twitter, the model qualitatively reproduces the observed relation between users' engagement and opinions, as well as opinion segregation in the interaction network. Our findings shed light on the mechanisms that may lie at the core of the emergence of echo chambers and polarization in social media.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Radicalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radicalization"},{"title":"Online youth radicalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_youth_radicalization"},{"title":"Algorithmic radicalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_radicalization"},{"title":"Deradicalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deradicalization"},{"title":"Islamist radicalization in European prisons - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamist_radicalization_in_European_prisons"},{"title":"Violent Radicalization and Homegrown Terrorism Prevention Act of 2007 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Violent_Radicalization_and_Homegrown_Terrorism_Prevention_Act_of_2007"},{"title":"Category:Radicalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Radicalization"},{"title":"Radicalized (Doctorow book) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radicalized_(Doctorow_book)"},{"title":"Classical radicalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_radicalism"},{"title":"Category talk:Radicalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category_talk:Radicalization"}]

Here are the search results for "Radicalization":

## Definition

Radicalization, also known as extremization, is the process by which an individual or a group comes to adopt increasingly radical views in opposition to a political, social, or religious status quo.

## Key Characteristics

Radicalization can result in both violent and nonviolent action, with academic literature focusing on radicalization into violent extremism (RVE) or radicalization leading to acts of terrorism.(no content)There is no universally accepted definition of radicalization, and one of the difficulties with defining it appears to be the importance of context to determine what is perceived as radicalization.

## Multiple Pathways

Multiple separate pathways can promote the process of radicalization, which can be independent but are usually mutually reinforcing.

## Online Radicalization

The phenomenon of "incitement to radicalization towards violent extremism" has grown in recent years, due to the Internet and social media in particular.(no content)Algorithmic radicalization refers to the concept that recommender algorithms on popular social media sites such as YouTube and Facebook drive users toward progressively more extreme content over time, leading to them developing radicalized extremist political views.

## Deradicalization

Deradicalization refers to a process of encouraging a person with extreme political, social or religious views to adopt more moderate positions on the issues.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the Twitter platform:

## What is Twitter?

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service and one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.(no content)Users can share short text messages, images, and videos in short posts.

## History and Ownership

Twitter was created by Jack Dorsey, Noah Glass, Biz Stone, and Evan Williams in March 2006 and was launched that July.(no content)The company went public in November 2013.(no content)The service is owned by the American company X Corp., which was established to succeed the prior owner Twitter, Inc. in March 2023 following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.

## Rebranding to X

In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024.

## Current Features

Now operating as X, the platform closely resembles its predecessor but includes additional features such as long-form texts, account monetization options, audio-video calls, integration with xAI's Grok chatbot, job search, and a repurposing of the platform's verification system as a subscription premium.

Web search results for query: "Social network"

Links: [{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"The Social Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Network"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Distributed social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_social_network"},{"title":"Social Networks (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Networks_(journal)"},{"title":"The Social Reckoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Reckoning"},{"title":"Threads (social network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Threads_(social_network)"}]

Here are the search results for "Social network":

## Definition and Concept

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.(no content)A social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.

## History

Georg Simmel authored early structural theories in sociology emphasizing the dynamics of triads and "web of group affiliations," and Jacob Moreno is credited with developing the first sociograms in the 1930s to study interpersonal relationships.

In the digital era, early social networking on the World Wide Web began in the form of generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), with many of these early communities focused on bringing people together to interact with each other through chat rooms.

## Modern Social Media

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.(no content)Social networking sites allow users to share ideas, digital photos and videos, posts, and to inform others about online or real-world activities and events with people within their social network.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

In the digital era, early social networking on the World Wide Web began in the form of generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), with many of these early communities focused on bringing people together to interact with each other through chat rooms.

## Modern Social Media

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.(no content)Social networking sites allow users to share ideas, digital photos and videos, posts, and to inform others about online or real-world activities and events with people within their social network.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

I've completed a web search for "Social influence psychology." Here's what I found:

## Definition and Overview

Social psychology is centered on the idea of social influence—the effect that words, actions, or mere presence of other people (real or imagined) have on our thoughts, feelings, attitudes, or behavior.

## Key Types of Social Influence

According to psychologists Morton Deutsch and Harold Gerard, two psychological needs lead humans to conform to the expectations of others: our need to be right (informational social influence) and our need to be liked (normative social influence).

**Informational Social Influence:** Informational influence (or social proof) is an influence to accept information from another as evidence about reality, and comes into play when people are uncertain.

**Normative Social Influence:** Normative influence is an influence to conform to the positive expectations of others.(no content)Normative social influence can be a very powerful, yet unconscious, motivator of behavior.

## Conformity

Conformity is a type of social influence involving a change in behavior, belief, or thinking to align with those of others or with normative standards, and it is the most common and pervasive form of social influence.

## Social Proof

Social proof (or informational social influence) is a psychological and social phenomenon wherein people copy the actions of others in choosing how to behave in a given situation.

The search results provide comprehensive information about how social influence operates in psychology across multiple dimensions, including famous experiments by researchers like Solomon Asch on conformity effects.

Web search results for query: "Polarization politics"

Links: [{"title":"Political polarization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization"},{"title":"Political polarization in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Political polarization in Turkey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_polarization_in_Turkey"},{"title":"File:The IRA, Social Media and Political Polarization in the United States, 2012-2018.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_IRA,_Social_Media_and_Political_Polarization_in_the_United_States,_2012-2018.pdf"},{"title":"Negative partisanship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_partisanship"},{"title":"Partisan sorting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partisan_sorting"},{"title":"Millennial politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millennial_politics"},{"title":"Conspiracy theories in United States politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conspiracy_theories_in_United_States_politics"},{"title":"Values, Voice and Virtue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Values,_Voice_and_Virtue:_The_New_British_Politics"},{"title":"Left–right political spectrum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Left-Right_politics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about political polarization:

## Definition and Overview

Political polarization is the divergence of political attitudes away from the center, towards ideological extremes.(no content)Scholars distinguish between ideological polarization (differences between the policy positions) and affective polarization (an emotional dislike and distrust of political out-groups).

## Types of Polarization

Political scientists typically distinguish between two levels of political polarization: elite polarization, which focuses on the polarization of the political elites like party organizers and elected officials, and mass polarization, which focuses on the polarization of the masses, most often the electorate or general public.

## Manifestations in Two-Party Systems

In a two-party system, a polarized legislature has two important characteristics: first, there is little-to-no ideological overlap between members of the two parties; and second, almost all conflict over legislation and policies is split across a broad ideological divide. This leads to a conflation of political parties and ideologies and the collapse of an ideological center.

## Polarization in the United States

Polarization has increased since the 1970s, with rapid increases in polarization during the 2000s onwards. According to the Pew Research Center, members of both parties who have unfavorable opinions of the opposing party have doubled since 1994, while those who have very unfavorable opinions of the opposing party are at record highs as of 2022.

## Related Concepts

Negative partisanship is the tendency of some voters to form their political opinions primarily in opposition to political parties they dislike. Whereas traditional partisanship involves supporting the policy positions of one's own party, its negative counterpart means opposing those positions of a disliked party.

Web search results for query: "Echo chamber social media"

Links: [{"title":"Echo chamber (media) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_chamber_(media)"},{"title":"Filter bubble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_bubble"},{"title":"Algorithmic radicalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_radicalization"},{"title":"Social influence bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence_bias"},{"title":"Talk:Echo chamber (media) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Echo_chamber_(media)"},{"title":"Reddit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reddit"},{"title":"Social media and political communication in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effects_of_social_media_on_political_communication"},{"title":"Social media as a news source - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_on_social_media"},{"title":"Influence of mass media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influence_of_mass_media"},{"title":"Social media use in politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_use_in_politics"}]

I've completed a web search on "Echo chamber social media." Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition and Concept

On social media, echo chambers limit exposure to diverse perspectives, and favor and reinforce presupposed narratives and ideologies.(no content)The term is a metaphor based on an acoustic echo chamber, in which sounds reverberate in a hollow enclosure.

## How Echo Chambers Form

Social platforms and online media outlets have established personalized algorithms intended to cater specific information to individuals' online feeds.(no content)Algorithms use users' past behavior and engagement activity to provide them with tailored content that aligns with their interests and beliefs, and commonly create echo chambers and sow radicalism and extremist thinking in these online spaces.

## Effects and Impacts

As echo chambers build upon identity politics and emotion, they can contribute to political polarization and neotribalism. Additionally, echo chambers tend to create an environment conducive to misinformation and disinformation, and individuals who consume information in echo chambers are less likely to be exposed to opposing viewpoints, which has been shown to increase negative attitudes toward them.

## Research Challenges

Empirical findings to clearly support these concerns are needed and the field is very fragmented when it comes to empirical results.(no content)However, researchers largely agree that echo chambers reduce exposure to opposing viewpoints and that social media platforms largely contribute to the formation and expansion of echo chambers.

Links: [{"title":"Echo chamber (media) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Echo_chamber_(media)"},{"title":"Filter bubble - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filter_bubble"},{"title":"Algorithmic radicalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Algorithmic_radicalization"},{"title":"Social influence bias - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_influence_bias"},{"title":"Talk:Echo chamber (media) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Echo_chamber_(media)"},{"title":"Reddit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reddit"},{"title":"Social media and political communication in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effects_of_social_media_on_political_communication"},{"title":"Social media as a news source - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/News_on_social_media"},{"title":"Influence of mass media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Influence_of_mass_media"},{"title":"Social media use in politics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media_use_in_politics"}]

I've completed a web search on "Echo chamber social media." Here's what the search revealed:

## Definition and Concept

On social media, echo chambers limit exposure to diverse perspectives, and favor and reinforce presupposed narratives and ideologies.(no content)The term is a metaphor based on an acoustic echo chamber, in which sounds reverberate in a hollow enclosure.

## How Echo Chambers Form

Social platforms and online media outlets have established personalized algorithms intended to cater specific information to individuals' online feeds.(no content)Algorithms use users' past behavior and engagement activity to provide them with tailored content that aligns with their interests and beliefs, and commonly create echo chambers and sow radicalism and extremist thinking in these online spaces.

## Effects and Impacts

As echo chambers build upon identity politics and emotion, they can contribute to political polarization and neotribalism. Additionally, echo chambers tend to create an environment conducive to misinformation and disinformation, and individuals who consume information in echo chambers are less likely to be exposed to opposing viewpoints, which has been shown to increase negative attitudes toward them.

## Research Challenges

Empirical findings to clearly support these concerns are needed and the field is very fragmented when it comes to empirical results.(no content)However, researchers largely agree that echo chambers reduce exposure to opposing viewpoints and that social media platforms largely contribute to the formation and expansion of echo chambers.

Web search results for query: "Homophily sociology"

Links: [{"title":"Homophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homophily"},{"title":"Heterophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heterophily"},{"title":"Network homophily - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_homophily"},{"title":"Assortative mixing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assortative_mixing"},{"title":"Blau space - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blau_space"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Homosociality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homosocial"},{"title":"Assortativity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assortativity"},{"title":"Terminology of homosexuality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homophile"},{"title":"Homogamy (sociology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homogamy_(sociology)"}]

Here are the search results for "Homophily sociology":

## Definition and Core Concept

Homophily is a concept in sociology describing the tendency of individuals to associate and bond with similar others, as in the proverb "birds of a feather flock together". The term comes from Ancient Greek, combining words meaning "same" and "friendship."

## Types of Homophily

The theory of homophily states that "similarity breeds connection." Homophily has two specific types: status homophily, which includes ascribed statuses such as race, gender, and age, and value homophily, which refers to shared beliefs and practices between individuals.

## Characteristics and Effects

Over 100 studies have observed homophily in some form or another, establishing that similarity is associated with connection. The categories on which homophily occurs include age, gender, class, and organizational role.(no content)Individuals in homophilic relationships share common characteristics (beliefs, values, education, etc.) that make communication and relationship formation easier.

## Opposite Concept

The opposite of homophily is heterophily or intermingling.(no content)Heterophily (meaning "love of the different") is the tendency of individuals to collect in diverse groups.

## Related Concepts

In the specific case of social networks, assortative mixing is also known as homophily. Additionally, homogamy is marriage between individuals who are, in some culturally important way, similar to each other and is a form of assortative mating.

Web search results for query: "Misinformation"

Links: [{"title":"Misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by governments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_governments"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation in the Gaza war - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_in_the_Gaza_war"},{"title":"Vaccine misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaccine_misinformation"},{"title":"COVID-19 misinformation by China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_misinformation_by_China"},{"title":"5G misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/5G_misinformation"},{"title":"Misinformation about violence by transgender people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_violence_by_transgender_people"},{"title":"Misinformation about the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misinformation_about_the_2024_Atlantic_hurricane_season"},{"title":"Seed oil misinformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seed_oil_misinformation"}]

I found comprehensive information about misinformation from the search results. Here's what I found:

## Definition and Characteristics

Misinformation is false or inaccurate information published without malicious intent, while disinformation is designed to mislead.(no content)Misinformation is typically spread unintentionally, mostly caused by a lack of knowledge, an error, or simply a misunderstanding, which contrasts with disinformation. Additionally, malinformation is correct information used in the wrong or harmful context, for instance, selectively publishing personal details to influence public opinion.

## Impact and Global Significance

In January 2024, the World Economic Forum identified misinformation and disinformation, propagated by both internal and external interests, to "widen societal and political divides" as the most severe global risks in the short term.(no content)The reason is that misinformation can influence people's beliefs about communities, politics, medicine, and more.

## How It Spreads

Social media platforms, such as Facebook, Instagram, X, etc., are designed in ways that enable information, including misinformation, to be posted and shared far more quickly than through other communication mediums.

## Historical Context

The term came into wider recognition during the mid-1990s through the early 2020s, when its effects on public ideological influence began to be investigated. However, misinformation campaigns have existed for hundreds of years.

The search results also contain information about specific areas where misinformation has been prevalent, including COVID-19, vaccines, 5G technology, and recent natural disasters.

Web search results for query: "Agent-based model simulation"

Links: [{"title":"Agent-based model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model"},{"title":"Agent-based social simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_social_simulation"},{"title":"GAMA Platform - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GAMA_Platform"},{"title":"Sugarscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sugarscape"},{"title":"Vensim - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vensim"},{"title":"RoboCup 3D Soccer Simulation League - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RoboCup_3D_Soccer_Simulation_League"},{"title":"Agent-based model in biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_model_in_biology"},{"title":"Agent-based computational economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-based_computational_economics"},{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Swarm (simulation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(simulation)"}]

## Agent-Based Model Simulation

Here's what I found about agent-based model simulation:

### Definition

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena. More specifically, an agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

### Key Characteristics

The process is one of emergence—the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. In other words, higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.(no content)Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

### Applications

ABMs are used in many scientific domains including biology, ecology and social science.(no content)Agent-based models can be used to simulate a wide variety of social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts.

### Implementation

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

## Agent-Based Model Simulation

Here's what I found about agent-based model simulation:

### Definition

Agent-based models are a kind of microscale model that simulate the simultaneous operations and interactions of multiple agents in an attempt to re-create and predict the appearance of complex phenomena. More specifically, an agent-based model (ABM) is a computational model for simulating the actions and interactions of autonomous agents (both individual or collective entities such as organizations or groups) in order to understand the behavior of a system and what governs its outcomes.

### Key Characteristics

The process is one of emergence—the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. In other words, higher-level system properties emerge from the interactions of lower-level subsystems.(no content)Most agent-based models are composed of: (1) numerous agents specified at various scales; (2) decision-making heuristics; (3) learning rules or adaptive processes; (4) an interaction topology; and (5) an environment.

### Applications

ABMs are used in many scientific domains including biology, ecology and social science.(no content)Agent-based models can be used to simulate a wide variety of social phenomena, including transportation, market failures, cooperation and escalation and spreading of conflicts.

### Implementation

ABMs are typically implemented as computer simulations, either as custom software, or via ABM toolkits, and this software can be then used to test how changes in individual behaviors will affect the system's emerging overall behavior.

Web search results for query: "Opinion dynamics"

Links: [{"title":"Mathematical models of social learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_models_of_social_learning"},{"title":"Sznajd model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sznajd_model"},{"title":"Social physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_physics"},{"title":"Jerusalem Institute for Market Studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jerusalem_Institute_for_Market_Studies"},{"title":"Eitan Tadmor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eitan_Tadmor"},{"title":"DeGroot learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeGroot_learning"},{"title":"Group dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_dynamics"},{"title":"Public opinion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_opinion"},{"title":"Opinion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion"},{"title":"Opinion journalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opinion_journalism"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about opinion dynamics:

## Overview

Opinion dynamics are modeled using mathematical models of social learning that aim to model how opinions form in social networks.(no content)In these models, people hold beliefs or opinions about various topics and learn about the world through observation or communication with others, with models trying to formalize how agents process information from their friends in the social network.

## Key Models

**DeGroot Model**: The DeGroot model, introduced in 1974, is one of the first models for describing how humans interact in social networks, where each agent takes a weighted average of their neighbors' opinions at each step to update their own belief.

**Sznajd Model**: The Sznajd model (or "United we stand, divided we fall" model) is a sociophysics model introduced in 2000 to gain fundamental understanding about opinion dynamics.(no content)The model states that if two people share the same opinion, their neighbors will start to agree with them, while if adjacent persons disagree, their neighbors start to argue with them.

## Research Questions

Main questions in the literature include whether social learning effectively aggregates scattered information and whether the consensus belief matches the true state of the world, as well as how effective media sources and prominent agents can be in influencing belief formation in a network.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Modeling Echo Chambers and Polarization Dynamics in Social Networks". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes a novel agent-based model)

**Key Findings:**

The paper was analyzed and 10 triples were extracted and validated:

1. **Echo chamber** (concept) - The paper analyzes this key phenomenon of limited perspective exposure in social networks
2. **Political polarization** (concept) - Central to modeling extreme opinion divergence 
3. **Misinformation** (concept) - Discussed as a concern linked to echo chambers
4. **Radicalization** (concept, **proposed**) - Novel reinforcing mechanism introduced by the paper for extreme opinion evolution
5. **Social network** (concept) - Foundation for modeling opinion dynamics
6. **Homophily** (concept) - Agent characteristic incorporated in the model
7. **Social influence** (concept) - Identified as a primary governing mechanism
8. **Twitter** (tool) - Used for empirical validation of the model
9. **Agent-based model** (method, **proposed**) - The novel modeling approach with heterogeneous agents
10. **Mathematical models of social learning** (concept) - Framework for opinion dynamics

**Validation Result:** All checks passed successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs and entity classifications. The analysis has at least 1 "uses" relation (required for all papers) and 2 "proposes" relations (required for contribution papers).
